Cyberpunk.name: Cyberpunk
Cyberpunk.description: Cyberpunk aesthetics are characterized by futuristic, dystopian settings with advanced technology and a gritty, neon-lit atmosphere.

Futurism.name: Futurism
Futurism.description: Futurism aesthetics embrace a forward-looking, visionary approach, often featuring sleek and minimalist designs with an emphasis on technology and progress.

examples: Unique Forms of Continuity in Space

Steampunk.name: Steampunk
Steampunk.description: Steampunk combines Victorian-era aesthetics with steam-powered machinery and retro-futuristic elements.

examples: Arcanum: Of Steamworks and Magick Obscura

Biopunk.name: Biopunk
Biopunk.description: Biopunk aesthetics explore the intersection of biotechnology and society, often featuring genetically modified organisms and ethical dilemmas.

Fantasy.name: Fantasy
Fantasy.description: Fantasy aesthetics transport viewers to magical worlds filled with mythical creatures, quests, and epic adventures.

examples: A Song of Ice and Fire

FilmNoir.name: Film Noir
FilmNoir.description: Film noir aesthetics are associated with dark, moody settings, crime, and morally complex characters.

SpaceOpera.name: Space Opera
SpaceOpera.description: Space opera aesthetics are known for their grandiose settings, epic battles, and intergalactic adventures.

examples: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy

Dystopian.name: Dystopian
Dystopian.description: Dystopian aesthetics depict bleak, oppressive, and often totalitarian futures.

examples: The Man in the High Castle

Horror.name: Horror
Horror.description: Horror aesthetics aim to frighten and unsettle viewers with supernatural or psychological elements.

Gothic.name: Gothic
Gothic.description: Gothic aesthetics are associated with dark, mysterious, and ornate settings, often featuring elements of horror and the supernatural.

PostApocalyptic.name: Post-Apocalyptic
PostApocalyptic.description: Post-apocalyptic aesthetics showcase worlds devastated by catastrophic events, often with desolate landscapes and resource scarcity.

Surrealism.name: Surrealism
Surrealism.description: Surrealistic aesthetics are characterized by dreamlike and absurd elements, challenging the viewer's perception of reality.

examples: The Persistence of Memory by Salvador Dalí
The Treachery of Images by René Magritte

Minimalism.name: Minimalism
Minimalism.description: Minimalist aesthetics focus on simplicity, clean lines, and a lack of excess, often conveying a sense of calm and order.

examples: Composition with Red, Blue, and Yellow by Piet Mondrian
Farnsworth House by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe
Barcelona Pavilion by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe
Swiss Railway Clock by Hans Hilfiker

Superhero.name: Superhero
Superhero.description: Superhero aesthetics are characterized by larger-than-life characters with special abilities, often engaged in battles between good and evil.

Shōnen.name: Shōnen
Shōnen.description: Shōnen aesthetics are characterized by action-packed adventures, strong friendships, and themes of courage, determination, and self-improvement.

Historical.name: Historical
Historical.description: Historical aesthetics are set in specific time periods, often featuring accurate depictions of historical events, cultures, and costumes.

Retro.name: Retro
Retro.description: Retro aesthetics draw inspiration from past eras, such as the '80s or '90s, featuring nostalgic elements like vintage technology, fashion, and pop culture.
